At a meeting of the Interfraternity
Board, in which nominations for next
year's officers of the Board were
made, the rushing agreement for 1935
was drawn up and approved.
Murphy, Delta Upsilon; Wiggall,
Sigma Phi Epsilon, and Miller, Kappa
Sigma, were nominated for president;
while Clarke, Omicron Kappa Omicron; Donnelly, Kappa Alpha, and
Sheer, Alpha Tau Omega, are running for secretary-treasurer.
The agreement as accepted is as
follows:
"The rushing season shall start on
Monday, October 7, 1935, and shall extend for three weeks. During this
period on Tuesday and Thursday
nights from 8:00 to 10:00 p. m. fraternity men may visit the freshmen
at their homes or rooms but may not
take them out or be with them at
other places. No organized party outside the fraternity houses will be permitted at any time during the rushing
season.
By 'organized party' is
meant:
"Any expenditure of money for entertainment of freshmen by fraternity
men. The only organized party permitted is on allotted 'Open House
Days.'
Open-House Days
"Friday ,October 18; Monday, October 21; Tuesday, October 22; Wednesday, October 23; Thursday, October 4, and Friday, October 25, from
8:30 a. m. until 1:00 a. m., will be
'Open House Days.' There will be
no restriction placed on the entertainment provided by the fraternities for
the freshmen on their allotted date,
except that the entertainment must be
confined to the Hopkins Chapter
House.
"'Open House' invitations to freshmen must be in the hands of the
President of the Interfraternity Board
by 4:00 p. m. on Wednesday, October
16. The President will see that the
invitations are placed in the proper
P. 0. boxes before 12:00 noon Thursday, October 17.
"On Saturday, October 26, the fraternities may entertain freshmen
without restriction until 1:00 a. m.
"A silent period extending from
1:00 a. m. Saturday, October 26, will
precede the presentation of bids, at

Six members of the Maryland Legislature will be present to give their
views on the Teachers' Oath Bill, now
up for approval or veto by Governor
Nice, at a public hearing to be held
in Latrobe Hall this afternoon at four
o'clock.

fracas as the underdoggest of underdogs, if one is to believe the prognosticators in the daily papers. But no
one on the Hopkins squad believed
that B. A. C. could enter any lacrosse
game without at least an even chance
of winning.
Scrimmaged To A Tie
The reasons for this confidence in
the ability of the Kelly-Lotz coached
aggregation were two scrimmages.
Nobody remembers the score of the
first one, but, as Don Kelly says, "it
was too short to matter." It was the
second scrimmage—the week before
the first game for each team. The
wood-wielding lasted an hour. At the
end of that time the count stood 1 to
1, which is known among us technical students of the game as a tie.
How anybody could have picked
St. John's to walk away with B. A. C.
is beyond me—and it is probably beyond the men who picked St. John's
by this time. Even without the scrimmage with Hopkins, the names in the
B. A. C. line-up should have warned
the general public.

Campaign For $200,000

The Johns Hopkins Hospital $200,000 sustaining fund drive will be formally opened on Tuesday, April 23,
with a banquet at the Belvedere Hotel, it was announced by the rommittee in charge.
The drive is being held to assure the
continuation of the Hospital's sickpoor care for the next two years. It
is expected that 300 persons will be
present at the banquet. Harriet Colston, Baltimore soprano, will sing at
the banquet.
Bowman, Tydings Expected
Among those expected to address
the gathering are Dr. Isaiah Bowman,
president-elect of the Johns Hopkins
University, and Senator Millard E.
Tydings of Maryland.
Dr. Joseph S. Ames, president of
the University, is one of those serving on the committee. Drs. Walter E.
Dandy, Harry R. Slash, Jr., Harvey
B. Stone, Alan C. Woodward, and
William A. Wilmer are also members
of the campaign body.
Mrs. Charles H. Baetjer is the
chairman of the women's auxiliary of
the Hospital, while Judge Henry D.
Harlan heads the Board of Trustees.
W. Frank Roberts, chairman of the
campaign, named George Weems
Williams to head the men's committee.
The committee follows:

The dance will be the last one given
by the board this year.
This is the second time this year
that undergraduates of the University
have come to the aid of the athletic
activities. Last March a "gymboree"
was held, and although it met with
much favor, not quite enough money
was received for payment on sweaters.
May Give More Benefits
Last year the Cotillion Board financed a training table for members
of the football team, but it was not
reintroduced this year. Several athletic scholarships

were also made

available td keep deserving athletes
in school.
According to T. Rogers Bartlett,
president of the Cotillion Board, the
board will give similar dances next
year if this attempt meets with the
approval of the student body. With
additional funds awards can be made
to winners in the various classes of
the intramural athletic teams.
Members of the Cotillion Board include Louis E. Reuling, Mead Johnson, Bill McConnell, Burton Cannon,
Brian Murphy, Dave Erck, and James
Bradford.

Ellis Tumpson,Business Manager
“Pitt News"Elected Pres. I. IV. A.
Ellis Tumpson, business manager
of the Pitt News, semi-weekly paper
of the University of Pittsburgh, was
elected president of the Intercollegiate Newspaper Association at the convention held last Friday and Saturday at Ursinus College.
C. W. Henderson, next business
head of the Alfred University Fiat
Lux, was named vice-president; Miss
Dorothy Italie, editor-in-chief-elect of
the Temple News, secretary, at the
conclave which shattered the 115-delegates record set at the Temple University meeting in March, 1934.
The University of Pittsburgh was
chosen as the site for the November,
1935, convention of the organization
which, having admitted Hood College
and West Chester State Teachers'
College to membership at last week's
meetings, now has 34 member papers
located in six states in the Middle
Atlantic area.
The Hatchet, George Washington
University paper, won the loving cup
offered to the paper chosen as best in

news and make-up and placed second
in editorial writing. The editorial cup
was won permanently by the Lehigh
Brown and White, having won first
place in the recent convention contest and more than six times in past
competitions. A new editorial cup will
be put into competition. The Lehigh
paper also won the new cup offered
for the best local advertising set-up.
Hyman M. Levin, who was president of I. N. A. in 1933-34, was characterized by the outgoing president,
Herbert S. Stare, of Gettysburg College, at the formal banquet which
closed the Ursinus conclave of 119
delegates, as "the motivating force
which has made possible the rapid
growth of I. N. A."
When Levin went into office in
April, 1933, there were only 25 member papers. When he retired in March,
1934, the I. N. A. had 31 member
papers and had made many steps for
improvement which are now being
further advanced by the organization.

SENATOR J. ALLAN COAD

Dr.Robert R.Wicks
ToSpeak On Apr.23
At"Y"Supper Club
"The College Student In A
Scared World" Is Topic
Of Princeton Chapel Dean
The speaker at the eighth monthly
supper club to be held in Levering
Hall this Tuesday evening at 6 p. m.,
April 23, will be Dr. Robert Russell
Wicks. He will talk on "The College
Student in a Scared World." Dr. Wicks
is at present dean of the chapel at
Princeton University.
He was born in Utica, New York,
and received his A.B. from Hamilton
College in 1904. He received his M.A.
in 1908, the same year he graduated
from the Union Theological Seminary.
The same year also found Dr. Wicks
ordained in the Congregational ministry, and a pastor in the Arlington
Avenue Presbyterian Church, in East
Orange, New Jersey.
Did "Y" Service During War
During the war, Dr. Wicks did Y.
M. C. A. service for six months, during which time he became well acquainted with the work being done by
the "Y" organization. He is also a
member of the Alpha Delta Phi fraternity.
Immediately following his address

to the supper club, Dr. Wicks will

Scabbard And Blade Answers
Scabbard and Blade is an organization whose purpose is the
dissemination of correct information
about the R. 0. T. C., national defense and other related questions.
The members of this society are sincere in their desire for world peace
and the elimination of war that
cures no ills and brings but bloodshed and economic waste to its
participants. That war is unceasing
on the face of the globe, is due to
the inherent defects of human naturq, and until such cancer spots
are removed by the surgery of understanding and education, the peoples of the earth will know war. It
is with the knowledge that conditions of this sort exist, regardless of
their justification, that Scabbard and
Blade attempts to review briefly the
questions at issue.
There can be but one answer, a
spontaneous reply, to the question,
"Would you bear arms in defense of
your country if the borders of the
U. S. were invaded?" Any argument would be lost upon one so
warped, so devoid of any spark of
patriotism that he would place his
ego above the welfare of the state.
"Would you bear arms for the U.
S. in the invasion of any country?"
The temper of the American people
is a tolerant, rather easy-going and
non-aggressive one.
History has
demonstrated this, and the future
will further vindicate the statement.
An invasion of another country presupposes a state of war. Such a war
would not be entered into without
popular consent because of the very
working of the government and the
ability of the electorate to express
itself through Congress.
A war
fought simply for territoial aggrandizement would be an improbability,
a practical impossibility. The verity
of this is settled best by honest introspection.
The question now resolves itself
into the desirability of waging
a conflict on home or on foreign soil.
What has been the experience of
France throughout her history?
From the time of Caesar to the present generation, France has been
ripped asunder by bloody wars that
have stripped her of wealth and population. And it has not been the
bearers of arms who have borne
the brunt of alien attack. Applying
the same conditions to America,
would her citizens place above national safety and utility a non-existent morality?
War recognizes no
morality. Is it our own existence
or the safety of our enemies that we
value more highly? The effete sophist or the maudlin sentimentalist
cannot digest this. He cannot understand that war means be strong
or perish. What became of historical figures who considered that their
destinies transcended those of their
countries?
We give you Benedict
Arnold, Philip Nolan, Aaron Burr,
and scores of others.
Scabbard and Blade does not
advocate a policy of maintaining an
army, navy and air force second to
none to insure us against possibilities of another great war. The positive economic hazard to national
stability is a far more pertinent
question than the problematic security offered by armaments of such
dimensions. Adequate national defense is imperative to national integrity, but the building of gigantic
instruments of war would inspire hatred, jealousy and suspicion in the
minds of other peoples. Let the expression, adequate national defense,
suffice of itself in this article. A suitable definition would be too lengthy
a digression.

When one stops to consider the
many ramifications involved in governmental control of arms and munitions industries one will say "No"
to that proposition. Every major industry in this country can be converted to the manufacture of arms,
munitions, and war supplies. Therefore, where is the line to be drawn
during peacetime? What is to be considered as a test for determining this
question? Yielding a point, let the
chemical and the steel industries be
considered as the prime offenders.
What percentage of their yearly outputs go to the production of armaments?
The answer is ridiculous.
For the sake of example, consider the
DuPont enterprises.
Their yearly
business during the war would constitute less than one per cent of their
activity in 1935. A consideration of
the savings that a government would
effect by the manufacture of its own
armaments leads to the contemplation
of the use to which such savings
would be put. Instead of being distribSuch a statement is obviously ab- stitution, as Dr. Lovejoy pointed out Ross Holloway's war bonnet and is

Quad Quips
By JACK STEIN
"Ladies and Hopkins students! I
stand before you on this memorable
day as a champion of suppression; as
a champion of low wages; as a champion of high taxes, and as a champion
of everything that needs champions—
capitalism, and the national league
included.
This oration is against those
against the signing of the Teathers'
Noathe Bill, requiring teachers to
wear rings on their noses. The size
of the ring is to be increased with the
years. A young instructor may wear
only a small ring through his nose
and that only of brass. Whereas the
head of a department may wear a
hoop of gold. The bill further states
that upon each ring the following information shall be engraved:
1—Name. Born? Why?
2—Who gave permission to teach?
—Why?
3—Why?
Now as I have previously stated, I
am definitely in favor of such a bill.
I offer three distinct and definite reasons, to support my nose rings bill.
The first reason, is that the Honor
System will be made more effective.
How? By the simple process of warning students when the professor is
approaching. The rustle of the ring
against the nasal bones will produce
a distinct and definite sound to which
students will attune their ears, so
that they will be amply warned.
My second reason, is the right of
the student when the lecture becomes
boring, to grab the professor by the
ring, and lead him gently out of the
lecture room. You know the old saying, You can lead a professor to lecture, but you can't make him think.
My third and most potent reason
why this bill should be signed by His
Royal Roundness, Governor D. Mise,
potent potentate of this potent state
of Fairyland (pretty fawncy, eh what
Cedric?), is .the fact that everybody
else says that it shouldn't be signed;
that common sense dictates it shall
not be signed; that popular opinion is
against it; and that Mrs. Roarin' Rarin' Dollarday is in favor of it, and
when she puts her weight behind a
bill, it is usually pushed through.

And thus, my fair disciples, I bid
thee harken well to my words for
behind them lie hidden pearls of wisdom.

The drunk got in a cab. "Where
to?" asked the cabby.
"What streets you got?" was the
reply.
"Plenty," smiled the humoring cabby.
"Gimme them all."
After several hours' driving, the
drunk asked how much he owed.
"Seven-fifty," he was told.
"Turn around and drive back to
thirty-five cents," he muttered.

Fast Midfield Man
LaMotte of St. John's and McGowan of Hopkins complete the defense.
Benny McGowan, at wing, is a fast
man with more stamina than most.
He is undoubtedly the biggest scoring threat among second defense men
in some time.
The attack is no less distinguished
than the defense. Bill Zeigler, who
played on the same St. John's teams
that Phil Lotz did, should start at
center. Bill was All-American attack
man at college, where he possessed a
wicked shot.
Wing attack will be Caleb Kelly of
Hopkins. He is a heady player and a
tricky shot. At first attack will be
either Georgie Alberts or Bob Douglas. Alberts is a former Baltimore
City College and Mount Washington
stickman. He is short and quite a contrast to Douglas, who is as big and
tough as they come. Douglas used to
dodge for Swarthmore and for West
Point.
Kelly Star And Coach
Don Kelly, attack coach and outhome, is, of course, the star among
these stars. If anybody is in for a
miserable afternoon, it is the man
who plays Kelly.
The team will be completed by
either Boots Ives or Doug Ramsey at
in-home. Boots used to lose his teeth
for Hopkins and Doug used to lose
weight for St. John's. Of the two,
Boots is the more aggressive, but
Doug is the more polished. He has
better stickwork and ranks as one of
the best shots in the game.
This does not mean that the host
team is expected to come out on the
short end of the score. The game will
be an even war from the first minute
to the sixtieth. As Don Kelly said:
"The game will be the closest and
most skilful of the year."

In their second home meet of the
season the Hopkins track team will
face Dickinson University in a dual
encounter this Saturday. The Jays
will be striving to break into the win
column to offset the defeat they suffered at the hands of Delaware in
their inaugural engagement of the
year.
The Black and Blue did not meet
Dickinson, in 1934, and consequently
are not very well informed on its
strength. However, Hopkins has defeated the school's cross-country
team rather easily for the past few
seasons, and thus is somewhat of a
favorite to repeat on the cinders Saturday.
The Jays will be in much better
condition against Dickinson than they
were last week,- as Coach Hambleton
has been working his men hard in an
attempt to round them into top shape.
In addition, Hopkins will be aided
greatly by the return of Paul Holtzman, star distance runner, who was
not able to compete against the Blue
Hens because of a bad ankle.

At a meeting of the Interfraternity
Board, in which nominations for next
year's officers of the Board were
made, the rushing agreement for 1935
was drawn up and approved.
Murphy, Delta Upsilon; Wiggall,
Sigma Phi Epsilon, and Miller, Kappa
Sigma, were nominated for president;
while Clarke, Omicron Kappa Omicron; Donnelly, Kappa Alpha, and
Sheer, Alpha Tau Omega, are running for secretary-treasurer.
The agreement as accepted is as
follows:
"The rushing season shall start on
Monday, October 7, 1935, and shall extend for three weeks. During this
period on Tuesday and Thursday
nights from 8:00 to 10:00 p. m. fraternity men may visit the freshmen
at their homes or rooms but may not
take them out or be with them at
other places. No organized party outside the fraternity houses will be permitted at any time during the rushing
season.
By 'organized party' is
meant:
"Any expenditure of money for entertainment of freshmen by fraternity
men. The only organized party permitted is on allotted 'Open House
Days.'
Open-House Days
"Friday ,October 18; Monday, October 21; Tuesday, October 22; Wednesday, October 23; Thursday, October 4, and Friday, October 25, from
8:30 a. m. until 1:00 a. m., will be
'Open House Days.' There will be
no restriction placed on the entertainment provided by the fraternities for
the freshmen on their allotted date,
except that the entertainment must be
confined to the Hopkins Chapter
House.
"'Open House' invitations to freshmen must be in the hands of the
President of the Interfraternity Board
by 4:00 p. m. on Wednesday, October
16. The President will see that the
invitations are placed in the proper
P. 0. boxes before 12:00 noon Thursday, October 17.
"On Saturday, October 26, the fraternities may entertain freshmen
without restriction until 1:00 a. m.
"A silent period extending from
1:00 a. m. Saturday, October 26, will
precede the presentation of bids, at

Scrimmaged To A Tie
The reasons for this confidence in
the ability of the Kelly-Lotz coached
aggregation were two scrimmages.
Nobody remembers the score of the
first one, but, as Don Kelly says, "it
was too short to matter." It was the
second scrimmage—the week before
the first game for each team. The
wood-wielding lasted an hour. At the
end of that time the count stood 1 to
1, which is known among us technical students of the game as a tie.
How anybody could have picked
St. John's to walk away with B. A. C.
is beyond me—and it is probably beyond the men who picked St. John's
by this time. Even without the scrimmage with Hopkins, the names in the
B. A. C. line-up should have warned
the general public.

Campaign For $200,000

The Johns Hopkins Hospital $200,000 sustaining fund drive will be formally opened on Tuesday, April 23,
with a banquet at the Belvedere Hotel, it was announced by the rommittee in charge.
The drive is being held to assure the
continuation of the Hospital's sickpoor care for the next two years. It
is expected that 300 persons will be
present at the banquet. Harriet Colston, Baltimore soprano, will sing at
the banquet.
Bowman, Tydings Expected
Among those expected to address
the gathering are Dr. Isaiah Bowman,
president-elect of the Johns Hopkins
University, and Senator Millard E.
Tydings of Maryland.
Dr. Joseph S. Ames, president of
the University, is one of those serving on the committee. Drs. Walter E.
Dandy, Harry R. Slash, Jr., Harvey
B. Stone, Alan C. Woodward, and
William A. Wilmer are also members
of the campaign body.
Mrs. Charles H. Baetjer is the
chairman of the women's auxiliary of
the Hospital, while Judge Henry D.
Harlan heads the Board of Trustees.
W. Frank Roberts, chairman of the
campaign, named George Weems
Williams to head the men's committee.

Ellis Tumpson,Business Manager
“Pitt News"Elected Pres. I. IV. A.
Ellis Tumpson, business manager
of the Pitt News, semi-weekly paper
of the University of Pittsburgh, was
elected president of the Intercollegiate Newspaper Association at the convention held last Friday and Saturday at Ursinus College.
C. W. Henderson, next business
head of the Alfred University Fiat
Lux, was named vice-president; Miss
Dorothy Italie, editor-in-chief-elect of
the Temple News, secretary, at the
conclave which shattered the 115-delegates record set at the Temple University meeting in March, 1934.
The University of Pittsburgh was
chosen as the site for the November,
1935, convention of the organization
which, having admitted Hood College
and West Chester State Teachers'
College to membership at last week's
meetings, now has 34 member papers
located in six states in the Middle
Atlantic area.
The Hatchet, George Washington
University paper, won the loving cup
offered to the paper chosen as best in

news and make-up and placed second
in editorial writing. The editorial cup
was won permanently by the Lehigh
Brown and White, having won first
place in the recent convention contest and more than six times in past
competitions. A new editorial cup will
be put into competition. The Lehigh
paper also won the new cup offered
for the best local advertising set-up.
Hyman M. Levin, who was president of I. N. A. in 1933-34, was characterized by the outgoing president,
Herbert S. Stare, of Gettysburg College, at the formal banquet which
closed the Ursinus conclave of 119
delegates, as "the motivating force
which has made possible the rapid
growth of I. N. A."
When Levin went into office in
April, 1933, there were only 25 member papers. When he retired in March,
1934, the I. N. A. had 31 member
papers and had made many steps for
improvement which are now being
further advanced by the organization.

The speaker at the eighth monthly
supper club to be held in Levering
Hall this Tuesday evening at 6 p. m.,
April 23, will be Dr. Robert Russell
Wicks. He will talk on "The College
Student in a Scared World." Dr. Wicks
is at present dean of the chapel at
Princeton University.
He was born in Utica, New York,
and received his A.B. from Hamilton
College in 1904. He received his M.A.
in 1908, the same year he graduated
from the Union Theological Seminary.
The same year also found Dr. Wicks
ordained in the Congregational ministry, and a pastor in the Arlington
Avenue Presbyterian Church, in East
Orange, New Jersey.
Did "Y" Service During War
During the war, Dr. Wicks did Y.
M. C. A. service for six months, during which time he became well acquainted with the work being done by
the "Y" organization. He is also a
member of the Alpha Delta Phi fraternity.

Scabbard And Blade Answers
Scabbard and Blade is an organization whose purpose is the
dissemination of correct information
about the R. 0. T. C., national defense and other related questions.
The members of this society are sincere in their desire for world peace
and the elimination of war that
cures no ills and brings but bloodshed and economic waste to its
participants. That war is unceasing
on the face of the globe, is due to
the inherent defects of human naturq, and until such cancer spots
are removed by the surgery of understanding and education, the peoples of the earth will know war. It
is with the knowledge that conditions of this sort exist, regardless of
their justification, that Scabbard and
Blade attempts to review briefly the
questions at issue.
There can be but one answer, a
spontaneous reply, to the question,
"Would you bear arms in defense of
your country if the borders of the
U. S. were invaded?" Any argument would be lost upon one so
warped, so devoid of any spark of
patriotism that he would place his
ego above the welfare of the state.
"Would you bear arms for the U.
S. in the invasion of any country?"
The temper of the American people
is a tolerant, rather easy-going and
non-aggressive one.
History has
demonstrated this, and the future
will further vindicate the statement.
An invasion of another country presupposes a state of war. Such a war
would not be entered into without
popular consent because of the very
working of the government and the
ability of the electorate to express
itself through Congress.
A war
fought simply for territoial aggrandizement would be an improbability,
a practical impossibility. The verity
of this is settled best by honest introspection.
The question now resolves itself
into the desirability of waging
a conflict on home or on foreign soil.
What has been the experience of
France throughout her history?
From the time of Caesar to the present generation, France has been
ripped asunder by bloody wars that
have stripped her of wealth and population. And it has not been the
bearers of arms who have borne
the brunt of alien attack. Applying
the same conditions to America,
would her citizens place above national safety and utility a non-existent morality?
War recognizes no
morality. Is it our own existence
or the safety of our enemies that we
value more highly? The effete sophist or the maudlin sentimentalist
cannot digest this. He cannot understand that war means be strong
or perish. What became of historical figures who considered that their
destinies transcended those of their
countries?
We give you Benedict
Arnold, Philip Nolan, Aaron Burr,
and scores of others.
Scabbard and Blade does not
advocate a policy of maintaining an
army, navy and air force second to
none to insure us against possibilities of another great war. The positive economic hazard to national
stability is a far more pertinent
question than the problematic security offered by armaments of such
dimensions. Adequate national defense is imperative to national integrity, but the building of gigantic
instruments of war would inspire hatred, jealousy and suspicion in the
minds of other peoples. Let the expression, adequate national defense,
suffice of itself in this article. A suitable definition would be too lengthy
a digression.

When one stops to consider the
many ramifications involved in governmental control of arms and munitions industries one will say "No"
to that proposition. Every major industry in this country can be converted to the manufacture of arms,
munitions, and war supplies. Therefore, where is the line to be drawn
during peacetime? What is to be considered as a test for determining this
question? Yielding a point, let the
chemical and the steel industries be
considered as the prime offenders.
What percentage of their yearly outputs go to the production of armaments?
The answer is ridiculous.
For the sake of example, consider the
DuPont enterprises.
Their yearly
business during the war would constitute less than one per cent of their
activity in 1935. A consideration of
the savings that a government would
effect by the manufacture of its own
armaments leads to the contemplation
of the use to which such savings
would be put. Instead of being distribSuch a statement is obviously ab- stitution, as Dr. Lovejoy pointed out Ross Holloway's war bonnet and is

Quad Quips
By JACK STEIN
"Ladies and Hopkins students! I
stand before you on this memorable
day as a champion of suppression; as
a champion of low wages; as a champion of high taxes, and as a champion
of everything that needs champions—
capitalism, and the national league
included.
This oration is against those
against the signing of the Teathers'
Noathe Bill, requiring teachers to
wear rings on their noses. The size
of the ring is to be increased with the
years. A young instructor may wear
only a small ring through his nose
and that only of brass. Whereas the
head of a department may wear a
hoop of gold. The bill further states
that upon each ring the following information shall be engraved:
1—Name. Born? Why?
2—Who gave permission to teach?
—Why?
3—Why?
Now as I have previously stated, I
am definitely in favor of such a bill.
I offer three distinct and definite reasons, to support my nose rings bill.
The first reason, is that the Honor
System will be made more effective.
How? By the simple process of warning students when the professor is
approaching. The rustle of the ring
against the nasal bones will produce
a distinct and definite sound to which
students will attune their ears, so
that they will be amply warned.
My second reason, is the right of
the student when the lecture becomes
boring, to grab the professor by the
ring, and lead him gently out of the
lecture room. You know the old saying, You can lead a professor to lecture, but you can't make him think.
My third and most potent reason
why this bill should be signed by His
Royal Roundness, Governor D. Mise,
potent potentate of this potent state
of Fairyland (pretty fawncy, eh what
Cedric?), is .the fact that everybody
else says that it shouldn't be signed;
that common sense dictates it shall
not be signed; that popular opinion is
against it; and that Mrs. Roarin' Rarin' Dollarday is in favor of it, and
when she puts her weight behind a
bill, it is usually pushed through.

And thus, my fair disciples, I bid
thee harken well to my words for
behind them lie hidden pearls of wisdom.

The drunk got in a cab. "Where
to?" asked the cabby.
"What streets you got?" was the
reply.
"Plenty," smiled the humoring cabby.
"Gimme them all."
After several hours' driving, the
drunk asked how much he owed.
"Seven-fifty," he was told.
"Turn around and drive back to
thirty-five cents," he muttered.
—Skipper.

"Name?" queried the immigration
official.
"Sneeze," replied the Chinese proudly.
The official looked hard at him. "Is
that your Chinese name?" he asked.
"No, 'Mellican name," said the Oriental blandly.
"Then let's have your native
name."
"Ah Choo."
—Log.

Translating the symbols, the Tokyo
telephone operator says,"The connection
is made — go ahead, please." Meaning
that now you can talk to Japan from any
telephone in the Bell System.
Interestingly, Japanese was the first
foreign language ever transmitted by telephone—when in the winter of 1876-77
three Japanese students at Harvard
visited Alexander Graham Bell in Boston.
These men have lived to see the day
when they can talk with Boston from
their homeland!
Seeking to put the whole world on such
easy speaking terms, Bell System service
now enables you to reach more than 93%
of the world's 33,000,000 telephones.

Fast Midfield Man
LaMotte of St. John's and McGowan of Hopkins complete the defense.
Benny McGowan, at wing, is a fast
man with more stamina than most.
He is undoubtedly the biggest scoring threat among second defense men
in some time.
The attack is no less distinguished
than the defense. Bill Zeigler, who
played on the same St. John's teams
that Phil Lotz did, should start at
center. Bill was All-American attack
man at college, where he possessed a
wicked shot.
Wing attack will be Caleb Kelly of
Hopkins. He is a heady player and a
tricky shot. At first attack will be
either Georgie Alberts or Bob Douglas. Alberts is a former Baltimore
City College and Mount Washington
stickman. He is short and quite a contrast to Douglas, who is as big and
tough as they come. Douglas used to
dodge for Swarthmore and for West
Point.
Kelly Star And Coach
Don Kelly, attack coach and outhome, is, of course, the star among
these stars. If anybody is in for a
miserable afternoon, it is the man
who plays Kelly.
The team will be completed by
either Boots Ives or Doug Ramsey at
in-home. Boots used to lose his teeth
for Hopkins and Doug used to lose
weight for St. John's. Of the two,
Boots is the more aggressive, but
Doug is the more polished. He has
better stickwork and ranks as one of
the best shots in the game.
This does not mean that the host
team is expected to come out on the
short end of the score. The game will
be an even war from the first minute
to the sixtieth. As Don Kelly said:
"The game will be the closest and
most skilful of the year."

HOPKINS

BELTS,

Jays Have High Hopes Of
Defeating College Not
Met In '34
In their second home meet of the
season the Hopkins track team will
face Dickinson University in a dual
encounter this Saturday. The Jays
will be striving to break into the win
column to offset the defeat they suffered at the hands of Delaware in
their inaugural engagement of the
year.
The Black and Blue did not meet
Dickinson, in 1934, and consequently
are not very well informed on its
strength. However, Hopkins has defeated the school's cross-country
team rather easily for the past few
seasons, and thus is somewhat of a
favorite to repeat on the cinders Saturday.
The Jays will be in much better
condition against Dickinson than they
were last week,- as Coach Hambleton
has been working his men hard in an
attempt to round them into top shape.
In addition, Hopkins will be aided
greatly by the return of Paul Holtzman, star distance runner, who was
not able to compete against the Blue
Hens because of a bad ankle.

The last few weeks have been harder on Hopkins than on the other leading lacrosse colleges, because the
Jays, with a young team—a team
that has more potentialities than any
other team—need every minute of
practice to gain in teamwork what
they lack in experience, something
that Maryland and St. John's already
have.
Right now, though, Hopkins has
something that other teams would
like to have—speed. The Blue team
is by far the fastest team in the

Weather Handicaps Team
This is true despite the fact that
both teams are severely handicapped
by lack of practice during almost two
weeks of impossible weather. Especially is this true of the clubmen, who
get few enough opportunities to practice even in the best of weather.

Jay Line-Up Revised
Coach Kelso Morrill has changed
his line-up slightly since the Dartmouth game, but only on the defense.
He is sure now that Lou Reuling
will start as custodian of the sacred
webbing—"unless something happens". And Elm Powell has been inserted at wing defense, shoving everybody back a position. That is, Rube
Parasew is now at first defense; Pete
Swindell at cover point, and Don
Naylor at point.
